awd_titl_txt: MSB-ECA: A macrosystems science training program: developing undergraduates' simulation modeling, distributed computing, and collaborative skills
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecologists are increasingly using computer models, involving extensive observations obtained through environmental sensor networks, to study lakes and forests and predict future change. Conducting this modeling, as well as understanding the model results, requires skills in data analysis, quantitative reasoning, and computing. However, modeling and computational skills are rarely taught in undergraduate classrooms, representing a major gap in training students to tackle complex environmental challenges. This project will develop a training program that teaches thousands of students across the U.S. the foundations of macrosystems ecology through simulation modeling. Through the program, instructors and their students will learn how to quickly and efficiently run the models by using new resources emerging from computer science. Thus, students will simultaneously learn the core concepts of macrosystems science and develop the skills needed to conduct the next generation of environmental research. These concepts and skills will be embedded within teaching modules centered on the frontier of macrosystems ecology, enabling undergraduate students to contribute to high-level macrosystems research. Engaging undergraduate students in hands-on modeling activities with real-world applications translates into a workforce with increased data science, systems thinking, and quantitative skills.

This project will create a training program (MacroSystems EDDIE: Environmental Data-Driven Inquiry & Exploration) that connects undergraduate students with new computing tools to teach them the foundations of macrosystems science using simulation modeling. These tools will be embedded in stand-alone teaching modules that will be widely applicable to a suite of disciplines and undergraduate student experience levels. The proposed modules represent the first formalized macrosystems science curriculum for undergraduates, which will be rigorously assessed, revised, and disseminated broadly for maximum impact through a partnership with the Science Education Research Center. The modules will be designed around areas of active research inquiry e.g., interacting local and regional effects on lake temperatures, carbon cycling, the incidence of algal blooms, continental-scale water policy and students will be encouraged to develop novel questions at the frontier of macrosystems science that they will answer using simulation models. As part of the training program, the students will share their results with Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON) scientific working groups to advance ongoing macrosystems research. The proposed program represents an innovative approach for teaching macrosystems biology to undergraduates and has the potential to advance undergraduate STEM education across the U.S. A minimum of 750 students will participate in the MacroSystems EDDIE modules during this project, with the potential for several thousands more through dissemination by Science Education Research Center. student participation in the Macrosystems EDDIE modules will generate scientific discoveries that will advance our understanding of macrosystems bio

por.por_cntn:
We developed a training program (Macrosystems EDDIE: Environmental Data-Driven Inquiry & Exploration) that teaches undergraduate students the foundations of macrosystems science using simulation modeling. Our team developed ready-to-use, stand-alone teaching modules based on critical concepts in macrosystems ecology ? cross-scale interactions, macroscale feedbacks, and teleconnections ? that are widely applicable to a suite of disciplines and undergraduate student experience levels. Through the program, instructors and students across the U.S. and around the world learn how to quickly and efficiently run millions of model simulations of land use and climate change scenarios based on GLEON (Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network) and NEON (National Ecological Observatory Network) lake sites by using an innovative distributed computing platform. Our teaching modules are all based in the R programming language and represent the first formalized macrosystems science curriculum for undergraduates, which has been rigorously assessed, revised, and disseminated broadly for maximum impact through a partnership with the Science Education Research Center (SERC) at Carleton College. All teaching modules are published in the Environmental Data Initiative (EDI) repository and all files are available for download at www.MacrosystemsEDDIE.org.

In total, we collected assessment data from ~500 students and ~40 instructors as part of 26 undergraduate and graduate courses at 21 colleges and universities during the three years of this project. When including courses that are not participating in our assessment, the total number of students who have completed a Macrosystems EDDIE teaching module is likely much higher, as there have been >14,200 unique views of our individual module pages on the SERC website and >2,739 file downloads. We estimate that at least ~3000 students have participated in the Macrosystems EDDIE program in total.

Our assessment data indicate that completion of one Macrosystems EDDIE module significantly increases undergraduate students' computational literacy, macrosystems ecology knowledge, and modeling skills. Post-module self-assessments of EDDIE students indicated significantly higher perceptions of proficiency and confidence in using a suite of computational tools (e.g., R programming) than in pre-module self-assessments. We also observed that the undergraduate students with ?the most to gain, gain the most,? as post-module growth in perceived proficiency and confidence in the use of computational tools was highest in students who had the lowest initial scores. This result suggests that participating in the Macrosystems EDDIE curriculum can help equalize student abilities and computational literacy while simultaneously building confidence for all students.

In addition, assessment data from ecology courses at a range of diverse universities demonstrate that completing Macrosystems EDDIE modules significantly increases student self-reported proficiency, confidence, and likelihood of future use of simulation models, as well as student ability to correctly interpret complex model output. Using models to develop and test hypotheses increased students? perceptions of the value of running many different simulations to study and predict potential effects of climate and land-use change on lakes. Consequently, our results suggest that integrating simulation modeling into undergraduate ecology courses will improve students? abilities to predict and understand the potential effects of global change on ecosystems.

The Macrosystems EDDIE program has provided pedagogical training to at least 37 ecology and environmental science faculty instructors and graduate teaching assistants across the U.S. and overseas in how to teach quantitative skills and data analysis through hands-on, inquiry-based activities. In total, our team has disseminated Macrosystems EDDIE module materials at 12 conferences and three workshops, as well as through a NEON video and the NEON educational website. We have partnered with NEON throughout this project, and have co-hosted a webinar on techniques for integrating NEON data into undergraduate classrooms. While our primary goal is to teach students macrosystems ecology and quantitative skills, we have found that introducing their instructors to the data and models within the modules has in many cases led to them using these resources for their own research programs beyond the classroom. In particular, we found that instructors who taught Macrosystems EDDIE modules were subsequently more interested in using NEON and GLEON data in their own research programs.

Finally, this project has provided the context for 6 modeling and education peer-reviewed publications and 14 publications in total. These publications were greatly facilitated by the scope of the Macrosystems EDDIE modeling work and data collection.
